review.title: Are SNOMED CT Browsers Ready for Institutions? Introducing MySNOM
review.abstract: SNOMED Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) is one of the most widespread ontologies in the life sciences, with more than 300,000 concepts and relationships, but is distributed with no associated software tools. In this paper we present MySNOM, a web-based SNOMED CT browser. MySNOM allows organizations to browse their own distribution of SNOMED CT under a controlled environment, focuses on navigating using the structure of SNOMED CT, and has diagramming capabilities.
histories: in Adrian Paschke, Albert Burger, Andrea Splendiani, M. Scott Marshall, Paolo Romano: Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on Semantic Web Applications and Tools for the Life Sciences, Berlin,Germany, December 8-10, 2010
review.COMMENTS: in Adrian Paschke, Albert Burger, Andrea Splendiani, M. Scott Marshall, Paolo Romano: Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on Semantic Web Applications and Tools for the Life Sciences, Berlin,Germany, December 8-10, 2010

metadata.title: Are SNOMED CT Browsers Ready for Institutions? Introducing MySNOM

sections.text: Keywords: SNOMED CT, Terminologies, Ontologies, Browser

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine - Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) has become a reference terminology [1] and an active research topic in both healthcare and semantic web communities [2]. One effective way to advance ontology research in the life sciences in general and SNOMED CT in particular is to provide appropriate software for researchers and practitioners. In particular, visualization and browsing tools can provide researchers and practitioners with a better understanding of the structure and complexity of biomedical terminology. There are lists of existing browsers, such as those from the National Library of Medicine of the United States1 and the National Health Service2 of the United Kingdom, to provide a reference for researchers and practitioners. However, these lists are not comprehensive, not up-to-date and have not been fully evaluated.

sections.heading: 2 Architecture Overview
sections.text: MySNOM is a web application that takes a multi-layered approach to decouple orthogonal functionality such as access control, graphical user interface, business logic and persistence. It is based on the lightweight, standard HTTP digest protocol [5] for user authentication and SQLite4 for quick access to terminology, and is hosted on a CGI-enabled web server in Figure 1.MySNOM is accessed through a web browser.

sections.heading: 3 User Interface and Diagramming Support
sections.text: MySNOM uses a clean user interface to examine all relationships related to a particular concept, including inverted relationships. It places the current concept in the center of the screen, with reference concepts on the left and reference concepts on the right. This structure follows the extended left-right direction of the flow and displays the natural directed graph structure of SNOMED CT. Every concept and relationship clicked on is clickable. Each concept or relationship clicked leads to a new screen and becomes the current term. The current concept is shown only once on the screen. Users can hover over any concept to further review the concept (see SNOMED CT code). A screenshot of MySNOM leafing through the term "chronic disease" is shown in Figure 2.MySNOM supports the generation of diagrams that clarify the context of a given concept or serve as a graphical resource that can be embedded in SNODqT documents.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have introduced an access-controlled, web-based, lightweight browser to provide structural navigation and concise diagrams for SNOMED CT using an authorized standard distribution of SNOMED CT. The browser can be viewed and tested under [8] and is freely available by contacting the author. As a future work, we plan to improve the prototype and add modularization support. Modularization support allows a user to store and export selected parts of SNOMED CT using ontological modularization techniques [9]. A tool with these features allows an in-depth study of the structure and capabilities of SNOMED CT. Thanks to Arantza Illarramendi, Jesu's Bermu'dez and Idoia Berges for their support, requests and feedback on MySNOM. Thanks to Stefan Martin Schulz and Maceñio Maceñio for their feedback on INCielo 1991 MaceCIM6BI Freiburg and their feedback.

referenceMentions.context: The Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine - Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) has become a reference terminology [1] and an active research topic in both the healthcare and the Semantic Web communities [2] [3].

The Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine - Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) has become a reference terminology [1] and an active research topic in both the healthcare and the Semantic Web communities [2] [3].

The Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine - Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) has become a reference terminology [1] and an active research topic in both the healthcare and the Semantic Web communities [2] [3].
In 2008, Rogers [4] performed a study of existing SNOMED CT browsers and developed a general catalog of desirable browsing features.
It relies on the lightweight and standard HTTP Digest protocol [5] for authentication of users, and SQLite to provide fast access to the terminology.
The diagramming module creates an intermediate representation of the browsed concept using the DOT language [6].
MySNOM uses Graphviz [7], an Open Source, fast, graph generation software, to generate the final diagram.
Modularization support will let a user store and export selected portions of SNOMED CT by using ontology modularization techniques [9].

In this paper we present MySNOM, a web-based SNOMED CT browser. MySNOM allows organizations to browse their own distribution of SNOMED CT under a controlled environment, focuses on navigating using the structure of SNOMED CT, and has diagramming capabilities.
